You mean before the US became a military and economic superpower and added social security and Medicare?  >Ignorant alarmism for literally no reason  The last time the President tried tariffs, he had to do a multi billion dollar bailout or the pork industry to save it. Comment: They are conservative.   Yes we didnâ€™t have an income tax before 1913, we did however have taxes including tariffs / customs duties, taxes on liquor and tobacco and even taxes on property  sale. So it wasnâ€™t a tax straight out of your paycheck, but you were still paying taxes. Donâ€™t see what the argument is here.  Also you donâ€™t solve budget gaps by waving a magic wand around, said production has to already exist here before you use it for any budget gaps.   You want production taxationâ€¦so taxing the creation of goods before they hit the marketâ€¦.and also boost production to offset budget gaps? You cant have both at the same time. They are completely opposite.  Itâ€™s not an ignorant alarmism stating that the tariffs imposed under Trump is an indirect tax hike to everybody in the US. No matter how many times Trump says China or any other country pays them, the reality is they donâ€™t, we do. They feel the pain of exporting less goods because of the tariffs, but again we pay them.  I do however hope that they eventually lead to new trade deals as thatâ€™s the assumed main objective for now.  Iâ€™m all for getting rid of income tax, but we have to have a **steady** alternative first before doing so considering that **half** of our economy depends on it. Iâ€™m not an economist but that sounds like a considerable chunk of the US economy to not mess around with sudden and not well thought moves.
